content: 7 times 140 sts round 45 patt 8 sts k2tog tbl k2tog patt 8 sts 7 times 126 sts round 47 patt 7 sts k2tog tbl k2tog patt 7 sts 7 times 112 sts round 49 patt 6 sts k2tog tbl k2tog patt 6 sts 7 times 98 sts round 51 patt 5 sts k2tog tbl k2tog patt 5 sts 7 times 84 sts round 53 patt 4 sts k2tog tbl k2tog patt 4 sts 7 times 70 sts round 55 patt 3 sts k2tog tbl k2tog patt 3 sts 7 times 56 sts round 57 patt 2 sts k2tog tbl k2tog patt 2 sts 7 times 42 sts round 59 patt 1 st k2tog tbl k2tog patt 1 st 7 times 28 sts round 61 k2tog tbl k2tog 7 times 14 sts next round using yarn a k2 decrease 7 times 7 sts break off yarn and draw up tightly finishing fasten_off centre of tam to ws weave in any loose ends to ws of tam press the tam gently on the ws using a warm iron over a damp cloth © copyright marie wallin 2016 page 2 fairisle technique fairisle is used when two or three colours are to be worked repeatedly along a row the colour not being used is stranded fairly loosely behind the stitches being worked it is very important not to pull this stranded yarn too tight as this will pucker your knitting and your stitch gauge will be too tight make sure to spread your stitches to ensure that they remain elastic i would recommend that you carry the stranded or floating yarn over no more than 5 stitches when using a dk or 4 ply yarn and no more than 3 stitches when using an aran or chunky yarn weave the stranded colour under and over the colour being worked if you have to knit a colour over more than the recommended amount key 62 60 a stone 190 b phantom 153 c ginger 154 50 d maritime 167 e seasalter 178 40 f jaffa 188 g mineral 181 h rage 150 30 i avocado 161 20 10 24 stitch repeat repeat 7 times in total © copyright marie wallin 2016 page 3 © copyright marie wallin 2016 page 4 www mariewallin com
